results.title: Emergency childbirth
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Paul Burnford Educational Films
results.brief_description: This film utilises actual birth footage along with animation, models and live-action in order to demonstrate the two main steps you will take in an emergency childbirth, ie evaluating the situation and assisting the delivery. In this instance the emergency birth is taking place in a park.

results.title: Emergency bridge - Hutt Gully
results.brief_description: Shows the step-by-step erection of a Bailey bridge by the Country Roads Board over a washaway on the Great Ocean Road, Victoria. In twelve hours, over 11 inches of rain had fallen, causing a gully 110 feet wide and 50 feet deep, thus completely stopping traffic. Twelve hours later traffic was flowing across a prefabricated bridge built by the Board as a temporary measure.
results.description: Shows the step-by-step erection of a Bailey bridge by the Country Roads Board over a washaway on the Great Ocean Road, Victoria. results.title: Emergency at Wallaby Creek
results.creator_credit: Roger Mirams, Pacific Films, Rod McNeil and David Baker
results.brief_description: An episode from the series: “The Terrific adventures of the terrible ten”. One of the boy’s of Ten Town falls ill and is taken to Ten town hospital. The boy hero of the story discovers dead fish in the dam and figures out that the aerial spraying from a crop duster is poisoning life in the area. He runs to tell the adults - there is no one in the police station - and the council water engineer won’t listen, so the hero goes and shuts down the town water supply to prevent poisoning. Cinematographer/Director of Photography: Bruce McNaughton

results.title: Emergence of personality
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personality Development”.
A combined forum version of three films in the Personality Development series: Baby meets his parents; Helping the child to face the don’ts; Helping the child to accept the do’s.

results.title: Emerald city [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Joan Long, New South Wales Film Corporation and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description: Emerald City is an hilarious romp which tells the tale of two couples working in the film industry and their desperate search to keep in tune with modern day pressures, without sacrificing modern day pleasures. Written by David Williamson, based on his play by the same name, the film stars John Hargreaves, Robyn Nevin and Nicole Kidman.

results.title: Embryonic development: the chick
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the development of the chick embryo, through all stages from germinal disc to hatching, employing animated diagrams and cine-micrography of the living embryo. Normal-speed and time-lapse photographic sequences, and animated diagrams, sometimes superimposed on microscopic views of the embryo, are used to clarify growth processes. (Five awards, including: Salerno; Golden Reel, USA)
results.description: This film illustrates the development of the chick embryo, through all stages from germinal disc to hatching, employing animated diagrams and cine-micrography of the living embryo. Normal-speed and time-lapse photographic sequences, and animated diagrams, sometimes superimposed on microscopic views of the embryo, are used to clarify growth processes. results.title: Embroidery and printed textiles
results.creator_credit: Educational Media Australia and John Fitzgerald
results.brief_description: Filmed in a workshop situation comprised of fifteen people. David Green demonstrates and explains in an informal discussion with his participants the various techniques used in embroidery and print making. He stresses the importance of experimenting with ideas and that there is a “marriage between stitch, fabric and dye colour”. The camera gives us a close-up look at many interesting and vibrant designs.

results.title: Embracing the Future
results.creator_credit: Mark Falzon, Michael Edols and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Historian and environmentalist Dr. Jonathon King points to an optimistic future, citing that humans are rational beings with the capacity to change and ensure a sustainable future. Phillip Toyne, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, demonstrates viable ways of reversing much of the damage done to our soil. Presenter Sue Hanckel concludes that “…we owe it to ourselves and our children to embrace the future with a vision that is life-affirming and positive.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Falzon, Michael Edols and Central Coast Media
